title: 108_hr2068
content:
The Act titled "Comprehensive Tuberculosis Elimination Act of 2003" includes provisions for an Advisory Council for the Elimination of Tuberculosis under Title I - Interagency Collaboration. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include the Advisory Council's duties in eliminating tuberculosis from the United States and developing a national plan. The Advisory Council is responsible for developing a national plan to eliminate tuberculosis in the United States, considering recommendations from the Institute of Medicine, addressing new technologies, and reviewing progress. Additionally, the Council will make recommendations for the U.S.'s involvement in global tuberculosis-control activities. The Advisory Council is responsible for developing a national plan to eliminate tuberculosis in the United States, focusing on high-incidence countries like Mexico and access to comprehensive tuberculosis control measures. The Council is composed of representatives from various federal agencies. The U.S.-Mexico Border Health Commission and other Federal departments and agencies are involved in significant activities related to tuberculosis. Members of the Advisory Council are appointed from individuals who are not federal government officers or employees. TITLE II--CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

SEC. 201. NATIONAL PROGRAM FOR TUBERCULOSIS ELIMINATION. Section 317E of the Public Health Service Act is amended to establish a national program for tuberculosis elimination. The Secretary may conduct research, demonstration projects, education, and training for the prevention, control, and elimination of tuberculosis. Research priorities include diagnosis, treatment of latent infection, drug-resistant strains, cases affecting specific populations, and clinical trials. Demonstration projects focus on developing regional capabilities for tuberculosis prevention and control. The Secretary may conduct research, demonstration projects, education, and training for the prevention, control, and elimination of tuberculosis. This includes collaboration with the Immigration and Naturalization Service to identify and treat immigrants with active or latent tuberculosis infection, public information and education programs, education and training for health professionals, support of model centers, and collaboration with international organizations and foreign countries. The Council is required to submit annual reports to Congress and the Secretary on activities related to tuberculosis. Authorization of appropriations is set at $528,000,000 for fiscal year 2004, with additional funding for subsequent years. The National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute's activities related to tuberculosis are amended under Subpart 2 of part C of the Public Health Service Act. Authorization of appropriations is set at $528,000,000 for fiscal year 2004. The Director of the Institute will expand research on tuberculosis, including efforts to eliminate the disease. Activities include enhancing research on tuberculosis and its relationship with HIV, as well as providing awards to faculty for developing curricula. The Director of the Institute may provide awards to support career development for professionals committed to researching pulmonary infections and tuberculosis. Authorization of appropriations includes $5,000,000 for tuberculosis academic awards for fiscal year 2004 and funding for subsequent years. For the purpose of supporting career development in researching pulmonary infections and tuberculosis, $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2004, with additional funding for the following years. SEC. 302. ACTIVITIES OF NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES. Section 447A of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include activities for developing a tuberculosis vaccine in accordance with a specific blueprint. Funding of $240,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 is also mentioned. Funding of $240,000,000 is allocated for fiscal year 2004, with additional funding for fiscal years 2005 through 2008 as needed. SEC. 303. JOHN E. FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCED STUDY IN THE HEALTH SCIENCES. The Public Health Service Act is amended to expand international activities for tuberculosis research and training through the John E. Fogarty International Center. The John E. Fogarty International Center expands international activities for tuberculosis research and training, modeled after the international training program for the human immunodeficiency virus. SEC. 304 amends the Public Health Service Act to include loan repayment programs for research on tuberculosis. The Secretary is required to reserve a portion of funds for contracts to conduct tuberculosis research.
